choices.text: Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar
Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar
Lymphocytosis with low protein and low sugar
Lymphocytosis with high protein and low sugar

questions.text: In cases of pneumococcal meningitis, which cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) finding is typical?(NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of pneumococcal meningitis, the typical cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings include pleocytosis, which is an increased number of white blood cells (WBCs), predominantly neutrophils. This inflammatory response is due to the infection caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. Additionally, there is usually an elevated protein concentration in the CSF due to the increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier and the presence of inflammatory proteins. The glucose level in the CSF is typically low because the bacteria consume glucose and the inflammatory response disrupts glucose transport. Therefore, the combination of pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar is characteristic of pneumococcal meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar: This option is incorrect because, while pleocytosis and low sugar are typical findings, the protein level in pneumococcal meningitis is usually high, not low.

 

Option C. Lymphocytosis with low protein and low sugar: This option is incorrect because lymphocytosis, which is an increase in lymphocytes, is more characteristic of viral meningitis rather than bacterial meningitis. Pneumococcal meningitis typically presents with pleocytosis (neutrophils).

 

Option D. Lymphocytosis with high protein and low sugar: This option is incorrect because, although the protein may be high and the sugar low, lymphocytosis is not typical for bacterial meningitis like pneumococcal meningitis. Bacterial meningitis usually presents with pleocytosis (neutrophils).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pneumococcal meningitis, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings typically include pleocytosis (increased white blood cells, predominantly neutrophils), high protein levels, and low glucose levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Paralysis of the tongue

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), affecting the lateral medulla. Key features include ipsilateral cerebellar signs (ataxia), Horner's syndrome, and sensory deficits with a classic crossed pattern (ipsilateral face and contralateral body). Dysphagia and dysarthria occur due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus (9th, 10th cranial nerves). However, tongue paralysis (hypoglossal or 12th nerve dysfunction) is notably absent because the hypoglossal nucleus lies medially in the medulla and is not affected in this lateral syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ataxia: This IS a characteristic feature of Wallenberg syndrome due to involvement of the spinocerebellar tracts and connections to the cerebellum, causing ipsilateral cerebellar signs.

 

Option B. Difficulty swallowing: This IS a characteristic feature due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus which supplies the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, resulting in dysphagia, dysphonia, and impaired gag reflex.

 

Option C. Crossed pattern of sensory loss: This IS a classic feature with ipsilateral face sensory loss (from trigeminal nucleus involvement) and contralateral body sensory loss (from spinothalamic tract involvement).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lateral medullary syndrome produces a distinctive constellation of ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia, Horner's syndrome, and facial sensory loss with contralateral body sensory loss, but spares the hypoglossal nerve (XII), so tongue paralysis is not part of this syndrome.

questions.text: Where are lipid rafts typically observed? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Plasma membrane

 

Explanation:


Lipid rafts are specialized microdomains within the plasma membrane that are enriched in cholesterol and sphingolipids. These membrane regions serve as organizing centers for the assembly of signaling molecules and influence membrane fluidity and protein trafficking. When these rafts become infiltrated with caveolin protein, they form flask-shaped membrane depressions called caveolae ("little caves").

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Ribosomes - Ribosomes are cellular structures composed of RNA and protein that function as sites of protein synthesis. They lack the lipid bilayer structure necessary for lipid raft formation.
  • Option b. Mitochondria - While mitochondria have an inner and outer membrane, lipid rafts are specifically located in the cell membrane (plasma membrane), not in mitochondrial membranes.
  • Option d. ER - The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a membrane-bound organelle involved in protein synthesis and lipid metabolism. Though it contains membranes, lipid rafts are primarily identified and characterized in the plasma membrane.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lipid rafts are cholesterol and sphingolipid-rich microdomains in the plasma membrane that can develop into caveolae and play important roles in cellular signaling, cholesterol regulation, and transcytosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with fever, myalgia, and headache for 3 days. He has recently returned from Southeast Asia. Blood smear shows P. vivax with normal vital signs and no organ dysfunction. What is the best initial treatment? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chloroquine

 

The patient presents with uncomplicated P. vivax malaria, as evidenced by the presence of typical symptoms (fever, myalgia, headache) without any signs of severe disease or organ dysfunction. In areas where chloroquine resistance is not reported, chloroquine remains the drug of choice for treating uncomplicated P. vivax malaria. After the initial treatment with chloroquine, primaquine should be given to prevent relapses by eliminating hypnozoites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Artemesinin combination therapy: While effective against P. vivax, ACT is reserved for areas with chloroquine resistance or when chloroquine treatment fails. It's not the first-line treatment in uncomplicated cases where chloroquine resistance is not a concern.

 

Option C. IV artesunate: This is reserved for severe malaria cases with organ dysfunction or high parasitemia. It's not indicated for uncomplicated P. vivax malaria.

 

Option D. Primaquine: While essential for radical cure of P. vivax malaria by eliminating hypnozoites, it is not the initial treatment. It should be given after the acute phase is treated with chloroquine, and only after checking G6PD status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In uncomplicated P. Vivax malaria without known chloroquine resistance, chloroquine remains the first-line treatment, followed by primaquine for radical cure to prevent relapses by eliminating hypnozoites.

questions.text: C-ANCA positivity is highly specific for?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wegener's granulomatosis

 

Explanation:

 

C-ANCA (cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) with specificity for proteinase-3 is highly specific for Wegener's granulomatosis, now called granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). More than 90% of patients with typical active granulomatosis with polyangiitis have detectable antibodies to proteinase-3. The specificity of antiproteinase-3 antibodies for Wegener's granulomatosis is very high (>95%), making it a valuable diagnostic marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa is ANCA-negative. It is a non-granulomatous medium vessel vasculitis without glomerulonephritis or pulmonary involvement, often featuring testicular involvement and microaneurysms visible on angiography.

 

Option C. Henoch-Schonlein purpura: HSP (now called IgA vasculitis) is characterized by IgA-mediated vasculitis with immune complex deposition rather than ANCA association. Diagnosis involves skin biopsy with direct immunofluorescence showing leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition in vessel walls.

 

Option D. Churg-Strauss syndrome: Now called eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), this condition is primarily associated with p-ANCA (perinuclear ANCA) with antimyeloperoxidase specificity rather than c-ANCA. Approximately 48% of patients with EGPA have circulating ANCA that is usually antimyeloperoxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C-ANCA with anti-proteinase-3 specificity serves as a highly specific serological marker for granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's), providing an important diagnostic tool that helps differentiate it from other vasculitides that are either ANCA-negative or associated with different ANCA patterns.

questions.text: What is the window period for thrombolysis in case of stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 41/2 hours

 

The window period for the administration of intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) in the case of an acute ischemic stroke is 4½ hours from the onset of symptoms. This time frame is critical as rtPA is most effective when administered early, aiming to dissolve the blood clot and restore blood flow to the affected part of the brain, thus minimizing or reversing the damage caused by the stroke.

 

Indications:

 

  • After Clinical diagnosis of stroke established
  • If onset of symptoms to time of drug administration </= 4.5 hours
  • If age >/= 18 years
  • CT scan showing no hemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory
  • Consent given by patient or surrogate

 

Contraindications:

 

  • Coma/stupor/ recent MI.
  • Major surgery in last 14 days/ GI bleeding in last 21 days/ minor stroke symptoms.
  • Rapidly improving symptoms.
  • Sustained BP > 185/110 mmHg despite treatment.
  • Platelets < 100,000; HCT < 25%; glucose < 50 or > 400 mg/dL.
  • Use of heparin within 48hrs and prolonged PTT or elevated INR.
  • Prior stroke or head injury within 3 months; prior intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic window for thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke using rtPA is up to 4½ hours from symptom onset, and strict criteria must be met to ensure the safety and efficacy of treatment. This timeframe is crucial for maximizing the potential benefits of the treatment while minimizing risks.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypothyroidism

 

Hypothyroidism can lead to various cardiac manifestations, including bradycardia and atrioventricular (AV) block. This is due to the metabolic effects of low thyroid hormone levels, which slow down the heart rate and can increase the risk of heart block. This type of AV block is generally reversible and often improves with appropriate thyroid hormone replacement therapy, such as levothyroxine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cushing's syndrome: Typically associated with other cardiovascular issues such as hypertension due to excessive cortisol levels, but not commonly with AV block.

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: Usually results in symptoms opposite to those of hypothyroidism, like tachycardia or atrial fibrillation, rather than AV block.

 

Option D. Pheochromocytoma: This condition, characterized by excess production of catecholamines, typically presents with episodic hypertension and tachycardia, not AV block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothyroidism causes reversible AV Block that improves with LT4 supplementation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented with complaints of paranasal sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge for the past few days. He also has a previous history of hemoptysis and hematuria. Imaging revealed multiple, bilateral, nodular cavitary infiltrates. Which of the following antibodies would be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) c-ANCA

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's presentation suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis. GPA triad typically involves:

 

  • ENT involvement: Sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge (sinusitis).
  • Pulmonary involvement: Hemoptysis and cavitating nodules on imaging.
  • Renal involvement: Hematuria and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

 

The characteristic antibody associated with GPA is c-ANCA (cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies), which targets proteinase 3.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies): Typically associated with systemic lupus erythematosus and other autoimmune diseases.

 

Option C. Anti-histone antibodies: Associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

 

Option D. Anti-Jo 1 antibodies: Associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is associated with c-ANCA (anti-proteinase 3 antibodies), presenting with ENT, pulmonary, and renal involvement.

questions.text: Which among the following indicates severe COVID-19 ? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SpO2 < 85% on room air


Severe COVID-19 is characterized by a significant drop in oxygen saturation. An SpO2 of less than 85% on room air indicates severe hypoxemia.

 

Any SpO2 of less than 90% indicate severe COVID and 90-93% indicates moderate COVID

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. RR >24/min: Indicates moderate, not severe, COVID-19. RR>30/min indicate severe COVID
 

Option B. MAP 70 mmHg: Does not specifically indicate severe COVID-19. Hemodynamic instability i.e. MAP <65 OR 65 or above with vasopressors indicates severe COVID. 
 

Option C. Lung infiltrates >42% on CT: Not a specific criterion for COVID-19 severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe COVID-19 is indicated by an SpO2 of less than 85% on room air.

questions.text: Which of the following features of stroke need not be treated? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neglect

 

Neglect after a stroke, often presenting as a lack of awareness of one side of the body, does not typically require direct medical treatment. While it may indicate a more severe stroke and can impact rehabilitation, many patients improve as they recover from other stroke symptoms. Therapy focuses on aiding patients in adapting to or compensating for this deficit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysphagia: Must be treated to prevent complications like aspiration pneumonia.

 

Option B. Spasticity: Requires management with medications (baclofen, tizanidine) or physical therapy to improve mobility and reduce discomfort.

 

Option C. Fever: Should be treated promptly as it can exacerbate brain injury and worsen outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While neglect is a common symptom following a stroke, it does not typically require specific medical treatment but rather supportive care and rehabilitation to help the patient adapt. Other physical symptoms such as dysphagia, spasticity, and fever require active medical management to prevent complications.

questions.text: Iritis is seen in all except: (INICET NOV 2020
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Iritis, or inflammation of the iris, is not commonly associated with Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA). Instead, RA is more commonly linked to other ocular conditions such as episcleritis and scleritis, which affect different parts of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SLE: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus can involve various parts of the eye, including the development of uveitis, which includes iritis.

 

Option B. Ulcerative Colitis: This inflammatory bowel disease is known to have extraintestinal manifestations including uveitis, which encompasses iritis.

 

Option C. Behcet's Disease: This is a multisystem inflammatory disorder that commonly affects the eyes, including the iris, making iritis a typical manifestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis is typically associated with scleral and episcleral inflammation rather than iritis, distinguishing it from other autoimmune conditions like SLE, Ulcerative Colitis, and Behcet's Disease that can present with iritis as a part of their systemic manifestations.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: What is Gaisbock-Najean syndrome? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Absolute polycythemia with thrombocytosis

 

Gaisbock-Najean syndrome is a rare variant of polycythemia vera characterized by absolute polycythemia with concurrent thrombocytosis. Unlike classic Gaisbock syndrome (which is relative polycythemia), this condition involves a true increase in red blood cell mass accompanied by elevated platelet counts. The condition is associated with the JAK2 V617F mutation and carries a higher risk of thrombotic complications compared to either condition alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Relative polycythemia: This refers to Gaisbock syndrome, where there is apparent increase in RBC mass due to decreased plasma volume without true increase in RBC production.

 

Option C. Secondary polycythemia: This occurs in response to increased erythropoietin production (like in chronic hypoxia) but doesn't typically present with significant thrombocytosis.

 

Option D. Primary polycythemia: While polycythemia vera is a primary polycythemia, this option is incomplete as it doesn't account for the characteristic thrombocytosis seen in Gaisbock-Najean syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The distinction between relative and absolute polycythemia, and recognize that some myeloproliferative disorders can present with concurrent abnormalities in multiple cell lines, particularly the association of polycythemia with thrombocytosis in certain variants.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oral Candidiasis

 

Oral candidiasis, while commonly associated with HIV infection, is not itself an AIDS-defining illness. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) list of AIDS-defining illnesses includes more severe manifestations such as candidiasis of the esophagus, trachea, bronchi, or lungs, but not oral candidiasis. This fungal infection is often seen in patients with HIV as a marker of immune suppression but does not qualify as an indicator of AIDS on its own.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalopathy attributed to HIV: This is an AIDS-defining condition, as it represents a direct effect of HIV on the brain resulting in cognitive impairment and motor dysfunction.

 

Option B. Invasive cervical cancer: This is considered an AIDS-defining illness due to the high risk and prevalence of this cancer in individuals with advanced HIV, reflecting a significant degree of immunosuppression.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium tuberculosis of any site: Tuberculosis, whether pulmonary or extrapulmonary, is an AIDS-defining illness due to its severity and frequency in the context of HIV-induced immune suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Infectious Disease/Chap 202

questions.text:
A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presented with withdrawal symptoms. His liver function tests showed:

 

AST 140 IU/L,

 

ALT 110 IU/L, and

 

GGT 500 IU/L.

 

Which of the following benzodiazepines can be safely administered to this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lorazepam

 

The patient's liver function tests indicate elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT, and GGT), suggesting potential alcoholic hepatitis or liver impairment. In such cases, choosing the appropriate benzodiazepine is crucial due to the liver's role in drug metabolism.

 

Lorazepam is a preferred benzodiazepine in patients with liver impairment for the following reasons:

 

  1. Short-acting: Lorazepam is a short-acting benzodiazepine, which means it has a shorter half-life and less risk of accumulation in the body compared to long-acting benzodiazepines.
  2. Minimal liver metabolism: Lorazepam undergoes minimal hepatic metabolism, which makes it safer for patients with impaired liver function. This reduces the risk of adverse effects and toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diazepam: Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine. It undergoes extensive hepatic metabolism, leading to active metabolites that can accumulate, especially in patients with liver dysfunction. This increases the risk of prolonged sedation and toxicity.

 

Option B. Alprazolam: Alprazolam, although shorter-acting than diazepam, still undergoes significant liver metabolism. It is not as safe as lorazepam in patients with compromised liver function.

 

Option C. Clonazepam: Clonazepam is also a long-acting benzodiazepine with extensive hepatic metabolism. Like diazepam, its use in patients with liver impairment can lead to accumulation and increased risk of side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with liver impairment, such as those with alcoholic hepatitis, lorazepam is the preferred benzodiazepine due to its short-acting nature and minimal hepatic metabolism.

questions.text: A person with dyspnea has slight limitation in physical activity and doing ordinary activity causes symptoms but he is asymptomatic at rest. Which class of New York Heart Association (NYHA) does he belong to? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Class II

 

NYHA Class II heart failure is characterized by slight limitation of physical activity. The patient is comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea, or angina. The key detail here is that ordinary activities cause symptoms, fitting the description of Class II.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I: Patients have no limitation of physical activity; ordinary physical activity does not cause symptoms.

 

Option C. Class III: Patients have marked limitation of physical activity; less than ordinary activity causes symptoms, but they are comfortable at rest.

 

Option D. Class IV: Patients have symptoms even at rest and are unable to carry out any physical activity without discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NYHA class –most powerful prognostic marker of HF.

 

  • Class 1 - asymptomatic with ordinary activities
  • Class 2 - symptomatic with ordinary activities, not at rest
  • Class 3 - symptomatic with < ordinary activity
  • Class 4 - symptomatic at rest

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling, compressing the trachea and esophagus. Histopathological assessment shows cell nests and pink extracellular amyloid stroma. What is the cell of origin of this tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parafollicular C cells

 

The presence of amyloid stroma in the context of a thyroid tumor is indicative of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland. These cells are responsible for secreting calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The amyloid stroma seen in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin-derived polypeptides.

 

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a unique type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular C cells. The hallmark of MTC is the presence of amyloid stroma, which results from calcitonin secretion by these cells.

 

Note -

 

  • The tumor marker for Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC) and Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC) is thyroglobulin.
  • The tumor marker for Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) is calcitonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Askanazy cells: These cells, also known as Hurthle cells, are large eosinophilic cells found in the thyroid gland but are typically associated with Hurthle cell carcinoma, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option C. Hurthle cells: These cells are a variant of follicular cells and are characteristic of Hurthle cell carcinoma. They do not produce amyloid stroma.

 

Option D. Follicular cells: These cells give rise to other types of thyroid cancers, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) and follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC). These tumors do not typically feature amyloid stroma and are more commonly associated with thyroglobulin as a tumor marker, not calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by amyloid stroma and originates from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and in type 2 respiratory failure was admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Non-Invasive PPV should be given

 

Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV) is often the initial treatment of choice for patients with COPD who present with an acute exacerbation and are in type 2 respiratory failure (characterized by hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis). NIPPV can improve gas exchange and reduce the work of breathing without the need for endotracheal intubation, thereby decreasing the risk of infection and other complications associated with invasive mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (IPPV): This is generally reserved for patients who fail NIPPV or present with severe acidosis, hemodynamic instability, or decreased level of consciousness that precludes the use of NIPPV.

 

Option C. IV corticosteroids: While systemic corticosteroids are commonly used in the management of acute COPD exacerbations, the initial focus in a patient in respiratory failure should be on stabilizing the patient's breathing and gas exchange. Corticosteroids can be administered orally or intravenously, but this would not be the primary concern in the immediate management.

 

Note - Oral steroids (prednisolone) is given for 5-14 days in acute exacerbations.

 

Option D. Permissive hypercapnia: This is a strategy used in mechanical ventilation where slightly elevated levels of carbon dioxide (hypercapnia) are tolerated to avoid high ventilatory pressures that can lead to lung injury, however pH is maintained above 7.3. It is applicable during mechanical ventilation if it becomes necessary but is not an initial management step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a COPD patient presenting with acute exacerbation and respiratory failure, non-invasive ventilation is the preferred initial management strategy to stabilize the patient's respiratory status, reducing the need for intubation and potentially improving clinical outcomes.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/COPD/chapter 292

questions.text: All are features of Conn's syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by an excess production of aldosterone, usually due to an adrenal adenoma.

 

The typical features of Conn's syndrome include:

 

  • Hypertension: Due to increased sodium and water retention.
  • Hypokalemia: Caused by increased potassium excretion.
  • Metabolic alkalosis: Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion and bicarbonate retention.

 

Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of Conn's syndrome. It is more commonly associated with conditions where there is a deficiency of aldosterone, such as adrenal insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis: Correctly associated with Conn's syndrome due to aldosterone's effect on renal tubular excretion of hydrogen ions.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Correctly associated with Conn's syndrome due to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Muscle cramps: Can be associated with hypokalemia seen in Conn's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism) is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Syndrome Z? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL more than 100 mg/dl

 

Syndrome Z also known as Metabolic Syndrome, is characterized by a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and diabetes. Syndrome involve the pressence of any three of the following five traits: 

 

Any 3/5 for diagnosis:

 

  1. Central Obesity: > 102cm (M),> 88 cm (F); [90(M), 80 cm (F) in Indians]: Only if questions specifically mention Indian population.
  2. BP > 130/85 mmHg
  3. FBS > 100 mg/dL/A1c
  4. Low HDL (in mg/dL): < 40 (F), < 50 cm(M)
  5. High TGL: > 150 mg/dL

 

Educational Objective:

 

While LDL cholesterol management is crucial in cardiovascular risk reduction, it is not one of the criteria for diagnosing Metabolic Syndrome, which focuses on abdominal obesity, blood pressure, fasting blood sugar, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides.

 

Reference - Harrison/Gastro/Fatty liver/Chap408

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient's symptoms? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right Ventricle

 

The patient’s presentation is characteristic of right ventricular failure, often secondary to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in chronic smokers.

 

Key clinical features include:

 

  • Shortness of breath: A common symptom in both left and right heart failure but is notably worsened by right heart failure due to fluid overload.
  • Bilateral pitting pedal edema: Indicates fluid retention, a hallmark of right ventricular failure.
  • Abdominal distension: Often due to ascites, which is related to increased venous pressure.
  • Elevated jugular venous pulse (JVP): Reflects increased central venous pressure due to right heart dysfunction.
  • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver): Due to congestion of blood in the liver secondary to increased venous pressure.

 

Right ventricular failure results from the right ventricle's inability to pump blood effectively to the lungs, leading to a backup of blood in the systemic venous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: Left ventricular failure primarily causes pulmonary congestion and edema due to the backflow of blood into the lungs. Symptoms like shortness of breath would predominate without the systemic venous congestion (e.g., pedal edema, elevated JVP, hepatomegaly) seen in right ventricular failure.

 

Option C. Aorta: An aortic abnormality would not directly cause the combination of symptoms described. Issues with the aorta generally result in systemic hypertension, aortic aneurysm, or dissection, which have different clinical presentations.

 

Option D. Mitral Valve: Mitral valve disease, particularly mitral stenosis or regurgitation, primarily affects the left atrium and ventricle, leading to pulmonary congestion and symptoms more indicative of left heart failure rather than the systemic congestion seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right ventricular failure is characterized by systemic venous congestion, which manifests as elevated jugular venous pressure, pitting pedal edema, hepatomegaly, and abdominal distension. This condition is often seen in chronic smokers due to the impact of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on the heart.

questions.text: Among the given options, murmur given in the image is associated with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mitral Regurgitation

 

The image provided indicates a murmur occurring between S1 and S2, which is described as a pan-systolic murmur. This type of murmur spans the entirety of systole.

 

Mitral Regurgitation produces a pan-systolic murmur due to the backward flow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium throughout systole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic Regurgitation: Characterized by an early diastolic murmur due to backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle.

 

Option C. Mitral Stenosis: Characterized by a mid-diastolic murmur due to obstructed blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Option D. Aortic Stenosis: Characterized by an ejection systolic murmur due to turbulent blood flow across a narrowed aortic valve during systole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral regurgitation is associated with a pan-systolic murmur, which is present throughout the systole and heard between the S1 and S2 heart sounds.

questions.text: A patient with ascites is found to have SAAG ≥ 1.1. All of the following causes except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TB peritonitis

 

The Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG) is calculated to differentiate between ascites caused by portal hypertension (high SAAG ≥ 1.1) and ascites caused by other reasons (low SAAG < 1.1). A SAAG value ≥ 1.1 indicates that the ascites is likely due to issues related to portal hypertension, such as cirrhosis, liver failure, or metastasis to the liver, which can also cause portal hypertension. Tuberculosis peritonitis, however, typically presents with a SAAG lower than 1.1 because it is not associated with portal hypertension but rather with peritoneal inflammation and capillary leak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cirrhosis: Directly associated with portal hypertension and commonly results in a SAAG ≥ 1.1.

 

Option B. Liver failure: Often leads to portal hypertension, causing a high SAAG.

 

Option C. Metastasis to liver: Can impede hepatic blood flow and increase portal pressure, also leading to a high SAAG.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Calculate the mid-parental height for a male child with a father who is 160 cm tall and a mother who is 145 cm tall: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 159 cm

 

To calculate the mid-parental height for a male child, the following formula is used

 

 

Given:

 

  • Father's height = 160 cm
  • Mother's height = 145 cm

 

Substituting the values into the formula:

 

 

Thus, the mid-parental height for the male child is 159 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mid-parental height for a male child is calculated by taking the average of the parents' heights and adding 6.5 cm. For a female child, you would subtract 6.5 cm instead.

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease presents to you with chest pain and palpitations. The ECG is shown below. Which of the following can be used in the management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intravenous amiodarone

 

The ECG indicates a monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT), which is a type of fast heart rhythm originating from one of the ventricles. The appropriate management of stable monomorphic VT involves the use of intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia: This condition is characterized by a consistent QRS complex morphology on the ECG, suggesting a single focus of origin within the ventricles.
  • Stable vs. Unstable VT: For stable VT (where the patient does not exhibit hemodynamic instability such as hypotension, altered mental status, or severe chest pain), the initial treatment involves intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.
  • Intravenous Amiodarone: According to the Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) guidelines, intravenous amiodarone is a recommended first-line therapy for stable monomorphic VT. Other options include procainamide and sotalol, but amiodarone is widely used due to its efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral metoprolol: Oral metoprolol is not typically used in the acute management of monomorphic VT. Beta-blockers like metoprolol are more suitable for rate control in atrial arrhythmias or for long-term management of heart rate.

 

Option B. Oral amiodarone: While amiodarone is appropriate for treating VT, oral administration is not suitable for acute management due to the need for rapid onset of action, which intravenous administration provides.

 

Option D. Intravenous metoprolol: Although intravenous beta-blockers can be used in certain arrhythmias, they are not the first-line treatment for monomorphic VT. Intravenous amiodarone or other antiarrhythmics are preferred for their effectiveness in stabilizing the ventricular rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs such as amiodarone, procainamide, or sotalol are recommended as first-line treatments according to ACLS guidelines.

questions.text: Patient affected with acute hepatitis B infection has currently come for follow up. Identify the serological marker marked in the image? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-HBc Ab

 

Anti Hbc Ab are produced against Hepatitis B infection. IgM is produced early and IgG later. Production of antibodies(A) is seen to correspond to gradual reduction of surface, envelop antigens.

 

 

Person recovering from acute infection may have negative anti HbS levels with low HbsAg levels. This is called window period where there is a lag between development of antiHbS and HbsAg levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-HBe Ab: These antibodies against the hepatitis B e antigen generally signify lower levels of viral replication. They are not represented at the marked point in the graph.

 

Option C. Anti-HBs Ab: These antibodies indicate recovery and immunity and typically appear after the disappearance of HBsAg, which occurs later than the timeframe shown for the marked serological marker.

 

Option D. HBsAg: This is the earliest detectable viral antigen to appear in the blood following infection but declines as Anti-HBc Ab and later Anti-HBs appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBc antibodies are crucial in diagnosing hepatitis B infection, as they appear early after exposure and persist throughout the infection. They are typically seen during the "window period" when HBsAg starts to wane and before Anti-HBs becomes detectable, indicating the body's initial immune response to the infection.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Hepatology/Viral hepatitis/ chap 339/

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anosmia

 

Kallmann syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the failure to start or fully complete puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It results from an isolated deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), leading to low levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), and consequently, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Anosmia is the hallmark feature of Kallmann syndrome and helps differentiate it from other causes of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Syndactyly in males: This refers to the fusion of fingers or toes and is not characteristic of Kallmann syndrome.

 

Option C. Precocious puberty in females: This is an early onset of puberty, which is not associated with Kallmann syndrome, as this condition causes delayed or absent puberty.

 

Option D. White forelock: This is a feature of Waardenburg syndrome, not Kallmann syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anosmia is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome, which is associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism due to isolated GnRH deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option in Guillain Barre syndrome? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroids

 

Steroids are not effective in the treatment of Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) and do not improve outcomes. This has been confirmed by multiple studies and clinical trials, leading to their non-recommendation in GBS management protocols.

 

While steroids have no role in acute GBS treatment, they are used in managing Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP), which is a related condition that requires long-term immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin): IVIG is a widely accepted treatment for GBS, where it is used to modulate the immune response. The typical regimen involves a total dose of 2 g/kg given over 2-5 days. IVIG is believed to neutralize circulating antibodies and reduce inflammation, leading to a decrease in the severity and duration of the disease.

 

Option C. Plasmapheresis: Also known as plasma exchange, plasmapheresis is used in GBS to remove harmful antibodies from the blood. This treatment is particularly useful in severe cases and is often started within the first two weeks of symptom onset for maximum effectiveness.

 

Option D. Ventilator support: Because GBS can lead to paralysis of the muscles used for breathing, ventilator support may be necessary for patients with severe respiratory muscle weakness. This supportive care is crucial in managing life-threatening complications of GBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steroids are not recommended for treating Guillain-Barre Syndrome due to their lack of efficacy in this specific condition, while IVIG and plasmapheresis are effective treatments. Supportive care, such as ventilator support, plays a vital role in managing severe cases where respiratory muscles are compromised.

 

Reference - Harrison neurology, Immune mediated neuropathies/GBS/Chap 447/12730

questions.text:
In a PHC, which of the following initial screening tests are used to diagnose diabetes? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. HbA1c >6.5
  2. Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL
  3. Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL
  4. 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

The initial screening tests for diagnosing diabetes in a primary health care setting generally include the following criteria:

 

2. Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL: A fasting blood glucose level of 126 mg/dL or higher on two separate occasions indicates diabetes. Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours.

 

3. Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL: A random blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL or higher, along with symptoms of diabetes, is sufficient for diagnosis. This test does not require fasting and can be taken at any time.

 

Other Options:

 

1. HbA1c >6.5%: While this test is beneficial for its ability to reflect average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months and does not require fasting, its higher cost and need for more sophisticated laboratory equipment make it less likely to be used at PHCs in India.

 

4. 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar: Part of the Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT), this test is more comprehensive but requires more time and resources, which may not be feasible in all primary care settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial screening tests for diagnosing diabetes in a primary health care (PHC) setting typically include fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL, and random blood sugar >200 mg/dL. These tests are widely accepted and feasible in most PHC settings.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presented with gum bleeding, easy bruising, and fatigue. He was suffering from fever for 1 month and on examination, he had pallor and a petechial rash distributed all over the body. His peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and his corrected reticulocyte count was 0.5%. Bone marrow revealed few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells. What should be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Idiopathic Acquired Aplastic Anemia

 

The patient's presentation of gum bleeding, easy bruising, fatigue, fever, pallor, and petechial rash suggests Pancytopenia. Pancytopenia can result from several conditions, but the key clues here are:

 

  • Bone marrow findings: The bone marrow shows few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells, indicating a hypocellular marrow.
  • Corrected reticulocyte count: A low corrected reticulocyte count (0.5%) indicates poor bone marrow response.

 

These findings are characteristic of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia, a condition where the bone marrow fails to produce adequate amounts of blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disseminated TB: Disseminated TB usually presents with systemic symptoms and may show a cellular bone marrow due to granulomas and other inflammatory changes, which is not consistent with the findings of a hypocellular marrow.

 

Option C. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH typically presents with hemolytic anemia, thrombosis, and sometimes pancytopenia. However, it usually shows a cellular marrow unless it is associated with aplastic anemia. In exams, PNH is generally considered a cause of cellular marrow.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS usually presents with a hypercellular or normocellular marrow with dysplastic changes. It can cause pancytopenia, but the marrow is typically not hypocellular except in rare cases of hypoplastic MDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia should be considered in patients presenting with pancytopenia, bleeding, bruising, fatigue, and hypocellular bone marrow without significant inflammatory or immature cells. The diagnosis is supported by a low corrected reticulocyte count and clinical findings consistent with bone marrow failure.

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is seen in methanol intoxication? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

 

Methanol intoxication leads to metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap & high osmolal gap. Methanol is metabolized in the body to formic acid, which is a strong acid. The accumulation of formic acid in the bloodstream results in an increase in hydrogen ion concentration, leading to acidosis. The high anion gap indicates that there are unmeasured anions (such as formate) contributing to the acidosis. In addition to causing a high anion gap, methanol intoxication also leads to a high osmolal gap, which is another diagnostic clue in cases of toxic alcohol ingestion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication does not cause alkalosis. Instead, it causes acidosis due to the production of formic acid.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because the acidosis caused by methanol intoxication is characterized by a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formate, a byproduct of methanol metabolism.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication leads to acidosis, not alkalosis, and the anion gap is elevated, not normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol intoxication causes metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following would most likely lead to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Squatting

 

In hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the intensity of the murmur is influenced by the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. Various maneuvers and medications can affect this obstruction by altering preload (the volume of blood in the ventricles before contraction) or afterload (the resistance the heart must pump against).

 

Squatting increases preload by squeezing the peripheral veins and increasing venous return to the heart. This increase in preload reduces LVOT obstruction, thereby decreasing the murmur's intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Digoxin increases contractility. In HCM, increased contractility can worsen LVOT obstruction, thereby increasing the intensity of the murmur and worsening the murmur.

 

Option C. Valsalva: The Valsalva maneuver reduces preload by decreasing venous return to the heart. This reduction in preload can increase LVOT obstruction, leading to a louder murmur.

 

Option D. Furosemide: By reducing preload, furosemide increases LVOT obstruction and murmur intensity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing preload (e.g., through squatting) reduces LVOT obstruction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, leading to a decrease in the murmur's intensity.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for patients with Congestive Heart Failure and an ejection fraction of < 40 percent is: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ACE + Beta Blocker

 

Explanation:

 

The recommended treatment for patients with heart failure and a reduced ejection fraction of less than 40 percent is a combination of an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker.

 

Recommendations for Treatment of Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction (<40%):

 

  • Prescribe an ACE inhibitor together with a beta-blocker for all heart failure patients with a Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction (LVEF) of < 40% and symptoms of heart failure unless a specific contraindication exists.
  • Use one of the three beta-blockers that have proven to reduce mortality in all stable patients (Carvedilol, Bisoprolol, and/or Metoprolol).
  • Use angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) in patients who cannot tolerate ACE inhibition.

 

Heart Failure with Reduced EF Treatment:

 

  • ACE-I or ARB AND Beta Blocker

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACE + Diuretic: While diuretics are used to manage fluid overload, they are not the first line for improving survival. The combination of an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker is preferred.

 

Option C. ACE + ARB: ARBs are used in patients who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors. The combination of an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker is preferred.

 

Option D. ACE + CCB: Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are not typically used as a first-line treatment for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. The combination of an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker is the cornerstone of therapy for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), as it significantly improves survival.

questions.text: Which of the following antiretroviral drugs has activity against both HIV and HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus)? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir

 

Acyclovir is effective against Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and has demonstrated activity against HIV in vitro and in some clinical studies. It acts as a nucleoside analog that inhibits viral DNA synthesis. When used in combination with antiretroviral therapy, it has been shown to reduce HIV viral load and slow disease progression in patients co-infected with HIV and HSV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tenofovir: While effective against both HIV and HBV, tenofovir does not have significant activity against HSV.

 

Option C. Nevirapine: A non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) that is specific to HIV and has no activity against other viruses.

 

Option D. Enfuvirtide: A fusion inhibitor specifically designed to prevent HIV entry into cells. It has no activity against other viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acyclovir is unique among antiviral drugs as it shows activity against both HSV and HIV. This dual activity is particularly important in managing patients with HIV-HSV coinfection, as HSV infection can increase HIV transmission and disease progression

questions.text: Which brain region's lesion leads to prosopagnosia?(NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occipito-temporal

 

Explanation:

 

Prosopagnosia, also known as face blindness, is primarily caused by lesions in the occipito-temporal region of the brain. This region includes the fusiform gyrus, which is part of the brain's system for recognizing faces. The occipito-temporal area links visual sensory inputs to the brain's face recognition network, crucial for identifying individuals by their facial features. Damage to this area disrupts the visual processing necessary for recognizing faces, leading to prosopagnosia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parietal lobe: Incorrect because while the parietal lobe is involved in sensory perception and integration, it does not specifically deal with face recognition.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe: Incorrect as the frontal lobe primarily manages higher cognitive functions and behavioral responses, not direct visual recognition tasks.

 

Option D. Parieto-occipital: Incorrect, although this region integrates visual information, it is not specifically responsible for face recognition, which is more closely tied to the occipito-temporal area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prosopagnosia is caused by damage to the occipito-temporal region, particularly affecting areas like the fusiform gyrus, crucial for facial recognition

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Pneumothorax? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased Chest Expansion.

 

Explanation:

 

In pneumothorax, air accumulates in the pleural space, causing the lung to collapse away from the chest wall. This leads to decreased chest expansion on the affected side. The physical examination findings in pneumothorax typically include an enlarged hemithorax with no breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and potentially a mediastinal shift to the contralateral side in tension pneumothorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased Breath Sounds: pneumothorax causes diminished or absent breath sounds on the affected side due to air in the pleural space separating the lung from the chest wall, preventing normal sound transmission.

 

Option C. Increased Vocal Resonance: pneumothorax actually decreases vocal resonance. The presence of air in the pleural space impedes sound transmission, resulting in decreased, not increased, vocal resonance.

 

Option D. Dull percussion note: pneumothorax produces a hyperresonant percussion note due to the presence of air in the pleural space. A dull percussion note would suggest fluid (as in pleural effusion) or consolidation (as in pneumonia).

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pneumothorax presents with classic physical findings of decreased chest expansion, absent breath sounds, and hyperresonant percussion on the affected side - the opposite of findings seen with pleural fluid or consolidation.

questions.text: Which drug is used for mass chemoprophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ciprofloxacin

 

Ciprofloxacin is commonly used for mass chemoprophylaxis in cases of meningococcal meningitis, particularly among close contacts of an infected individual. It is effective in preventing the spread of Neisseria meningitidis, the bacterium responsible for meningococcal disease. Ciprofloxacin is preferred due to its broad-spectrum activity, ease of administration as a single-dose regimen, and good penetration into the cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloramphenicol: While used for treatment of meningococcal meningitis, it is not used for chemoprophylaxis.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Not used in the prophylaxis or treatment of meningococcal meningitis.

 

Option D. Penicillin: Although used for treatment, penicillin is not typically used for prophylaxis against meningococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciprofloxacin, Rifampicin, Ceftriaxone is indicated in the chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis for close contacts to prevent secondary cases.

 

Ceftriaxone is preferred in children < 18 years and pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a headache, describing it as the worst headache of his life. Initial NCCT shows SAH. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CT Angiography

 

Explanation:

 

The description of the "worst headache of his life" is highly suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). When an initial non-contrast CT (NCCT) confirms SAH, the next step is to identify the source of bleeding, which is most commonly an aneurysm.

 

CT Angiography is the preferred next step to localize the aneurysm and plan further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lumbar puncture: Indicated if the initial CT scan is negative and there is still suspicion of SAH, to check for xanthochromia.

 

Option C. MRI brain: Not the initial choice for acute SAH diagnosis or aneurysm localization.

 

Option D. V-P shunt: Used for hydrocephalus management, not for immediate SAH diagnosis and management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage on CT, the next step is CT Angiography to identify and localize the source of bleeding.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to emergency following an episode of syncope during his morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 5yrs back. His ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for patient? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DC Cardioversion.

 

The given ECG shows wide QRS complex with no P wave suggesting the diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia. Clinical features of exercise intolerance and the presence of ischemic heart disease also support the diagnosis of VT. Since patient hemodynamically unstable, next best step is DC Cardioversion. For stable patients, amiodarone is given intravenously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine and D. Lidocaine: These are antiarrhythmic drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias but are less appropriate in acute, hemodynamically unstable VT where immediate cardioversion is preferred.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Typically used for heart rate control in atrial fibrillation and not suitable for acute VT, especially in the context of hemodynamic instability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with ventricular tachycardia and signs of hemodynamic instability, DC Cardioversion is the recommended treatment to quickly restore normal heart rhythm. Pharmacological treatments like amiodarone may be considered post-cardioversion for rhythm stabilization in stable patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific test for the detection of recent monkeypox infection in a patient who has received smallpox vaccination in the past? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Monkeypox-specific IgM detection

 

In patients with prior smallpox vaccination, cross-reactive antibodies can complicate diagnosis. Monkeypox-specific IgM detection can differentiate between recent monkeypox infection and past smallpox vaccination immunity. This test is particularly useful because IgM antibodies are specific to recent infection and typically appear 5-8 days after symptom onset, making it the most specific test in previously vaccinated individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: While ELISA can detect antibodies, standard ELISA tests may not differentiate between monkeypox and other orthopoxviruses, including vaccine-induced antibodies.

 

Option B. PCR: Though highly sensitive for detecting viral DNA, PCR cannot differentiate between active infection and viral DNA remnants in recently vaccinated individuals.

 

Option C. Western blot: While useful for protein detection, it's not specific enough to differentiate between monkeypox infection and vaccine-induced immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with prior smallpox vaccination, monkeypox-specific IgM detection is crucial for accurate diagnosis of recent monkeypox infection, as it can differentiate between vaccine-induced immunity and current infection.

choices.text: An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O-
His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

 

  1. Due to the decreased risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) with related transplants, related donor transplants are still favored over unrelated donor transplants.
  2. Rh incompatibility has no impact on the success of transplants (Rh antigen is only found on the surface of RBCs, not on the parenchymal cells of the graft).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Syngeneic transplantation (donation from identical twins) has been shown to increase the risk of relapse in cases of hematologic malignancies and is therefore not a source of donor that is advised.

 

Option B: Umbilical cord transplant is not usually recommended.

 

Option C: While ABO compatibility is vital when selecting a donor, this is merely a slight ABO discrepancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with acute myeloid leukemia, the optimal donor choice would generally be an HLA identical sibling, despite any ABO blood type differences, due to the lower risk of complications and better overall survival outcomes. Blood type discrepancies, especially in Rh factor, are manageable in the context of stem cell transplants.

 

Reference - Harrison/Transplant/Chap 104

choices.text: Fasciculation at the level of lesion
Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion

questions.text: Which of the following does not help in the localization of lesions in the spinal cord? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contralateral hemiplegia

 

When localizing lesions in the spinal cord, it is crucial to understand how different tracts and their associated functions are affected:

 

  1. Corticospinal Tract: Damage to this tract results in ipsilateral hemiparesis (weakness) below the level of the lesion. This is because the corticospinal tract crosses over (decussates) at the medulla, above the spinal cord. Therefore, damage at the spinal cord level affects the same side of the body.
  2. Posterior Column: Damage here leads to ipsilateral loss of light touch, vibration, proprioception, and pressure. Similar to the corticospinal tract, the posterior column pathways decussate above the spinal cord.
  3. Spinothalamic Tract: This tract, responsible for pain and temperature sensation, crosses at the level of the spinal cord itself. Damage to the spinothalamic tract results in contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

 

Given these pathways, contralateral hemiplegia suggests a lesion above the spinal cord, typically above the pyramidal decussation in the brainstem or higher. Therefore, it does not help in localizing lesions within the spinal cord itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fasciculation at the level of lesion: Fasciculations are a sign of lower motor neuron involvement, which can occur at the level of the spinal cord lesion due to damage to the anterior horn cells. This helps in localizing the lesion.

 

Option C. Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion: The presence of both upper motor neuron (UMN) and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs can be indicative of a spinal cord lesion. UMN signs (such as spasticity and hyperreflexia) occur below the lesion, while LMN signs (such as fasciculations and muscle atrophy) occur at the level of the lesion.

 

Option D. Bladder involvement: Bladder and bowel dysfunction are common in transverse spinal cord lesions. This is due to the involvement of the autonomic pathways that control these functions, helping to localize the lesion within the spinal cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contralateral hemiplegia indicates a lesion above the spinal cord, specifically above the level of pyramidal decussation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Child-Pugh scoring? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatinine

 

Explanation:

 

Child-Pugh scoring system is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. It involves five clinical measures of liver disease, including:

 

  1. Albumin
  2. Bilirubin
  3. Prothrombin Time (INR)
  4. Ascites
  5. Hepatic Encephalopathy

 

Creatinine is not included in the Child-Pugh scoring system. Instead, it is a component of the MELD (Model for End-Stage Liver Disease) score. The MELD score includes three parameters: creatinine, bilirubin, and INR. If it's MELD sodium, then it includes creatinine, bilirubin, INR, and sodium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Albumin is a component of the Child-Pugh score. It helps assess the synthetic function of the liver.

 

Option B. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is another component of the Child-Pugh score. It indicates the liver's ability to excrete bile.

 

Option C. Prothrombin Time (INR): Prothrombin Time, measured as INR, is included in the Child-Pugh score to evaluate the liver's ability to produce clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Child-Pugh scoring system does not include creatinine as a parameter. Instead, creatinine is a part of the MELD score.

 

Note - The MELD score uses three parameters: Creatinine; Bilirubin and INR (International Normalized Ratio), so k/a CBI score. MELD Sodium Score includes Creatinine; Bilirubin; INR and sodium

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease, also known as Graves' ophthalmopathy. This condition is associated with autoimmune thyroid disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the tissues around the eyes, leading to inflammation and swelling. This results in the characteristic bulging of the eyes, known as proptosis or exophthalmos.

 

Thyroid eye disease is particularly common in middle-aged individuals and can cause both unilateral (one eye) and bilateral (both eyes) proptosis. The pathophysiology involves the expansion of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, leading to the protrusion of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft tissue tumour in orbit: While soft tissue tumors in the orbit can cause proptosis, they are not the most common cause in middle-aged individuals. These tumors can be benign or malignant and require imaging studies for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Optic nerve meningioma: This type of tumor is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and can lead to proptosis. However, it is less common compared to thyroid eye disease.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Although cavernous hemangioma is the most common orbital tumor in adults, it is not the most common cause of proptosis. These benign vascular tumors can cause proptosis if they become large enough to displace the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease (Graves' ophthalmopathy).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has ptosis and limb weakness that worsens in the evening. She was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. What is the first-line drug used?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyridostigmine

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms are characteristic of myasthenia gravis, a chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles. The hallmark of this condition is fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest.

 

The primary mechanism involves antibodies that attack the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing communication between nerves and muscles.

 

The first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis is pyridostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. Pyridostigmine works by increasing the amount of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby enhancing communication between nerves and muscles, which helps to improve muscle strength.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used to reduce inflammation and modulate the immune system. While it can be used in myasthenia gravis, it is not the first-line treatment. It is typically considered when patients do not adequately respond to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: An immunosuppressant that can be used in myasthenia gravis, particularly in patients who are not responsive to corticosteroids or those who have significant side effects from steroids. It is not a first-line treatment due to its side effect profile

 

Option D. Plasma exchange: This is a procedure used in severe cases of myasthenia gravis or during myasthenic crisis. It rapidly reduces the level of circulating antibodies by removing them from the blood. This is not used as a first-line treatment but rather as an acute intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis is pyridostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that improves muscle strength by increasing acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension and is on multiple antihypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spironolactone

 

The ECG shows tall, tented T waves, absent P waves (atrial standstill), and a severely widened QRS complex. These are classic signs of severe hyperkalemia.

 

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can cause hyperkalemia. It is known for increasing potassium levels in the blood by inhibiting the effects of aldosterone, leading to decreased excretion of potassium in the urine.

 

Therefore, the drug most likely responsible for the ECG findings is Spironolactone due to its potent potassium-sparing effects leading to severe hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrochlorothiazide: Causes hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Can cause mild hyperkalemia but not to the extent seen in the ECG.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Does not affect potassium levels significantly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spironolactone, a potassium-sparing diuretic, can cause severe hyperkalemia, which is characterized by tall, tented T waves, absent P waves, and widened QRS complexes on an ECG.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with abdominal pain. Evaluation revealed the presence of renal calculi and high PTH levels. What should be done next? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tc-99m Sestamibi

 

The patient has elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels and renal calculi, which suggests primary hyperparathyroidism. The next step in the management of primary hyperparathyroidism is to localize the overactive parathyroid gland(s). This is most effectively done using a Tc-99m Sestamibi scan. The Sestamibi scan helps in identifying the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland by detecting increased uptake of the radioactive tracer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound thyroid: While useful for identifying thyroid nodules, ultrasound thyroid is not the best tool for localizing hyperactive parathyroid glands in primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. DEXA scan: DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) scan is used to assess bone density and diagnose osteoporosis. While osteoporosis can be a consequence of hyperparathyroidism, the DEXA scan is not used to localize the hyperactive parathyroid glands.

 

Option D. Radioactive iodine uptake study:  This study is used primarily for evaluating thyroid function, particularly in cases of primary hyperthyroidism, to determine the pattern of iodine uptake in the thyroid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with primary hyperparathyroidism indicated by high PTH levels and renal calculi, a Tc-99m Sestamibi scan is the appropriate next step to localize the overactive parathyroid gland(s).

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB shows resistance to which of the following drugs? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isoniazid and rifampicin

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, which are the two most powerful first-line anti-TB drugs. This resistance makes MDR-TB more difficult and longer to treat than drug-susceptible TB.

 

Isoniazid and rifampicin: These are the cornerstone drugs in the treatment of TB. MDR-TB's resistance to these drugs necessitates the use of second-line medications and a longer, more complex treatment regimen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and fluoroquinolone: While resistance to fluoroquinolones can occur, it characterizes pre-extensively drug-resistant (pre-XDR) TB or extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB, not just MDR-TB.

 

Option B. Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolone resistance typically occurs in more advanced drug-resistant TB cases like pre-XDR and XDR-TB.

 

Option D. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and kanamycin: This option refers to XDR-TB, which includes resistance to at least isoniazid, rifampicin, a fluoroquinolone, and a second-line injectable drug such as kanamycin.

 

Note – Old definition of XDR - H and R resistance plus at least one fluoroquinolone resistance plus at least one second line injectable drug resistance like aminoglycosides (amikacin, kanamycin and capreomycin).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most important first-line anti-TB drugs.

choices.text: Acute HBV infection in window period
HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.text:
The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  • HBsAg - NR,
  • Anti HBs - NR,
  • Anti HBc IgM - NR,
  • Anti HBc total - positive,
  • HBeAg - NR,
  • Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's serological markers indicate the following:

 

  • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.

 

  • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.

 

  • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.

 

  • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.

 

  • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.

 

Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.

 

Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presented with generalized fatigue and lethargy. Her general examination revealed a few superficial lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions. Labs – TC: 7400, Hb: 12.8 g/dL, and Platelets: 244,000. She had a normal DC and lymph node biopsy revealed architectural distortion, infiltration with cells with indented nucleus, and prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. Immunophenotyping showed CD10 and Bcl2 were positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Follicular Lymphoma

 

The diagnosis of follicular lymphoma is supported by several key features in this patient's presentation and pathology findings:

 

  • Architectural distortion and infiltration with atypical cells: These findings on lymph node biopsy are consistent with follicular lymphoma.
  • Immunophenotyping: The presence of CD10 and Bcl2 positivity is characteristic of follicular lymphoma. CD10 is a marker indicating origin from the germinal center, and Bcl2 positivity suggests the presence of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2, which is a hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkitt Lymphoma: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with c-myc overexpression due to the t(8;14) translocation. It often presents with a high proliferation index and does not typically express Bcl2.

 

Option B. Hodgkin Lymphoma: Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. Sometime, PD1 overexpression. Immunophenotyping usually shows CD15 and CD30 positivity, not CD10 and Bcl2.

 

Option C. Mantle Cell Lymphoma: Mantle cell lymphoma is characterized by cyclin D1 overexpression due to the t(11;14) translocation. It is usually CD5 and cyclin D1 positive, not CD10 and Bcl2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma often presents with lymphadenopathy and generalized symptoms such as fatigue. Key diagnostic features include CD10 and Bcl2 positivity on immunophenotyping, reflecting its germinal center origin and overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mannitol

 

The patient is experiencing Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), a complication that can occur during or after hemodialysis, especially in patients with initially very high urea levels undergoing dialysis for the first time. DDS is caused by a rapid decrease in urea levels in the blood, leading to a sudden change in osmolarity, which causes water to move into the cells, resulting in cerebral edema and neurological symptoms such as drowsiness and seizures.

 

  • Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS): This condition is characterized by neurological symptoms due to cerebral edema caused by rapid changes in blood urea levels during dialysis.
  • Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic is used to treat cerebral edema by reducing intracranial pressure and drawing fluid out of the brain cells, thus decreasing cerebral edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bumetanide: This loop diuretic is used for fluid overload but not specifically indicated for treating cerebral edema in DDS.
